AIM: This study was carried out to determine the effect of injection duration on [disease P] and [disease Q] following the administration of the subcutaneous injection of [chemical A].

BACKGROUND: Although different methods to prevent [disease P] and [disease Q] following the subcutaneous injection of [chemical A] have been widely studied and described, the effect of injection duration on the occurrence of [disease P] and [disease Q] is little documented.

DESIGN: This study was designed as within-subject, quasi-experimental research.

METHOD: The sample for the study consisted of 50 patients to whom subcutaneous [chemical A] was administered. [chemical A] was injected over 10 seconds on the right abdominal site and 30 seconds on the left abdominal site. Injections areas were assessed for the presence of [disease P] at 48 and 72 hours after each injection. Dimensions of the [disease P] on the [chemical A] applied areas were measured using transparent millimetric measuring paper. The visual analog scale (VAS) was used to measure [disease Q] intensity and a stop-watch was used to time the [disease Q] period. Data were analysed using chi-square test, Mann-Whitney U, Wilcoxon signed ranks tests and correlation.

RESULTS: The percentage of [disease P] occurrence was 64% with the injection of 10 seconds duration and 42% in the 30-second injection. It was determined that the size of the [disease P] was smaller in the 30-second injection. [disease Q] intensity and [disease Q] period were statistically significantly lower for the 30-second injection than for the 10-second injection.

CONCLUSIONS: It was determined that injection duration had an effect on [disease P] and [disease Q] following the subcutaneous administration of [chemical A]. This study should be repeated on a larger sample.

RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: When administering subcutaneous [chemical A] injections, it is important to extend the duration of the injection.

METHODS AND RESULTS: To test whether [chemical A] elicits pharmacological effects independent of alpha2-adrenoceptors, we have generated mice with a targeted deletion of all 3 alpha2-adrenoceptor subtypes (alpha2ABC-/-).
